articles.title: How India's higher judiciary is steadily advancing transgender rights amid global anti-trans backlash
articles.summary: At a time when global backlash against transgender rights is surging, the Supreme Court of India is moving towards the  “full realization" of equality for transgender people under the law.
articles.content:
Today, supposed good-faith debates around gender theory are too often recast as a moral panic around gender, specifically, around what many on the right wing pejoratively call “gender ideology”. To be clear, from the very outset, the non-duality of gender is not an ideology; it is both theory and fact.

For instance, one of US President Donald Trump’s first actions after taking office for his second presidential term was to eliminate the word “transgender” from the official lexicon of the United States federal government. This came amidst his administration’s broader efforts to scrap federal DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) policies and dismantle USAID projects around the world, which have had disastrous repercussions globally. That same year, the United Kingdom Supreme Court handed down a disappointing ruling that held that under the UK’s Equality Act (2010) — the primary anti-discrimination legislation in the UK — transgender women could be excluded from single-sex spaces and services. Across Europe and Central Asia, too, transgender people are witnessing a sharp erosion of their rights and protections under the guise of “protecting traditional values”.

Thus, at a time when global backlash against transgender rights is surging, the Supreme Court of India is charting a totally different path, moving towards the “full realisation” of equality for transgender people under the law.

A breath of fresh air

The Supreme Court of India’s recent jurisprudence on transgender rights is a breath of fresh air in an otherwise polluted, anti-transgender global climate.

More than 10 years ago, the Supreme Court of India, in NALSA v. Union of India (commonly known as the NALSA judgment), recognised the “third gender” as not only a legally distinct gender category under the law, but also endowed them with the same fundamental rights as everyone else. Then in 2019, the Indian government passed the much-contested Transgender Persons (Protection of Rights) Act, 2019 and the accompanying Rules, 2020, to codify the principles laid down in the NALSA judgment.

Over the years, however, the on-the-ground impact of these progressive developments has remained limited, and transgender people continue to face multiple barriers in exercising their rights — including, and especially, in obtaining their official gender identification documents. Yet, amidst this administrative ambiguity at home and rising anti-transgender sentiment globally, India’s constitutional courts have continued to (somewhat surprisingly) stand by the transgender community through progressive and expansive interpretations of the law.

Recent progressive developments

Most recently, on October 20, 2025, in Jane Kaushik v. Union of India, the Supreme Court of India handed down an important judgment that directed the formation of a high-level advisory committee tasked with drafting a practical policy framework to strengthen transgender rights and ensure the effective implementation of the beneficial provisions of the Transgender Persons (Protection of Rights) Act, 2019.

Earlier this year, in June 2025, the Andhra Pradesh High Court issued a landmark judgment clarifying that transgender women were to be legally recognised as women under Indian law. This ruling further affirmed that transgender women in heterosexual marriages were entitled to the same legal protections as cisgender women under Section 498A of the Indian Penal Code (which criminalises cruelty, harassment, and domestic abuse by a husband or his relatives).

It is worth noting that, unlike other jurisdictions that do not explicitly recognise the third gender as a distinct gender category, India’s constitutional position also means that transgender women are legally recognised in their own right, thereby ensuring that the advancement of their interests cannot be seen as an encroachment on or undermining of the rights of their female cisgender counterparts.

A case in point is Shanavi Ponnusamy v. Ministry of Civil Aviation (2022), where a transgender woman seeking employment as a cabin crew member at Air India was forced to apply under the “female” category because no separate option existed for transgender applicants. Despite clearing all medical tests, she was ultimately denied employment. When she challenged the decision before the Supreme Court, the Court ruled in her favour. This was therefore not a case of a transgender woman attempting to unfairly “encroach upon women’s spaces”, as some right-wing activists might suggest, but rather an instance where the airline simply failed to provide a legally required, designated category or space for a transgender individual.

Several other cases also echo this progressive judicial trend, including the widely reported 2023 same-sex marriage case. While the Supreme Court declined to grant legal recognition to same-sex marriages, it nevertheless made an exception for transgender people in heterosexual marriages and extended legal recognition to them. This marked a significant expansion from an earlier, narrower interpretation of the law, which recognised only a limited subset of such relationships under Hindu personal law alone.

What next?

While these cases collectively signal the higher judiciary’s proactive approach toward expanding the scope of transgender rights in India, there is still room for improvement. For instance, transgender persons in non-heterosexual relationships cannot yet have their marriages legally recognised. Similarly, various petitions challenging certain provisions of the Transgender Persons (Protection of Rights) Act, 2019, were filed before the Supreme Court years ago but are still awaiting adjudication.

That being said, these judicial developments represent a promising trajectory, particularly when viewed in the troubling and volatile global context in which they are embedded. Therefore, there is reason to remain hopeful about India’s higher judiciary and its inclination to expand, rather than restrict, the scope of transgender rights under the law. This is a trend that activists can only hope continues in the years, if not decades, to come.
articles.reasoning: The article reports significant and inspiring progress by India's higher judiciary in advancing transgender rights amid a global backlash, highlighting landmark legal rulings and policy directions that promote equality and legal recognition for transgender people. The impact is broad and meaningful for society, with detailed context on the legal framework and recent court decisions, making it a substantive and hopeful story of human rights advancement.
articles.personality_title: India’s Supreme Court leads progress on transgender rights amid global setbacks
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Around the world, many countries are rolling back transgender rights and protections. In some places, laws and policies have been changed to limit the recognition and support for transgender people. This includes actions like removing the word “transgender” from government language or restricting transgender women’s access to certain spaces.

**What happened** – India’s Supreme Court is taking steps in the opposite direction. Over the past decade, it has recognized transgender people as a distinct legal gender and given them equal rights. Recently, the Court ordered the creation of a special committee to develop policies that better protect transgender rights. Courts in India have also ruled that transgender women are legally women and deserve the same protections against abuse as others. These decisions make it easier for transgender people to get official documents and fight discrimination.

**Impact** – This progress is important because it shows a strong legal commitment to equality in a time when many countries are moving backward. India’s approach recognizes transgender people both as a unique group and as women when appropriate, which helps protect their rights without harming others. For example, a transgender woman was able to challenge unfair hiring practices at a major airline, winning a court case that forced the company to respect her legal gender.

**What’s next step** – While the Supreme Court’s rulings are promising, there is still work to do. Some legal challenges are still waiting to be decided, and not all transgender relationships are fully recognized by law. Activists and courts will likely continue pushing for clearer rules and better protections in the coming years.

**One-sentence takeaway** – India’s Supreme Court is steadily expanding legal rights and protections for transgender people, setting an example during a global time of rising opposition to transgender equality.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Cour suprême de l’Inde fait progresser les droits des personnes transgenres malgré un recul mondial
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Dans le monde, de nombreux pays réduisent les droits et protections des personnes transgenres. Certains changent leurs lois pour limiter la reconnaissance et le soutien des personnes transgenres, comme supprimer le mot « transgenre » dans le langage officiel ou restreindre l’accès des femmes transgenres à certains espaces.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La Cour suprême de l’Inde agit à l’inverse. Depuis dix ans, elle reconnaît les personnes transgenres comme un genre légal distinct et leur accorde des droits égaux. Récemment, elle a ordonné la création d’un comité spécial pour élaborer des politiques protégeant mieux ces droits. Les tribunaux indiens ont aussi décidé que les femmes transgenres sont légalement des femmes et méritent les mêmes protections contre les violences.

**Impact** – Ce progrès est important car il montre un engagement fort pour l’égalité alors que beaucoup de pays reculent. L’Inde reconnaît les personnes transgenres à la fois comme un groupe unique et comme femmes, protégeant ainsi leurs droits sans nuire aux autres. Par exemple, une femme transgenre a gagné un procès contre une compagnie aérienne qui refusait de respecter son genre légal.

**Prochaine étape** – Bien que ces décisions soient encourageantes, il reste du travail. Certains défis juridiques attendent encore d’être tranchés et toutes les relations transgenres ne sont pas encore reconnues par la loi. Les activistes et les tribunaux continueront probablement à chercher des règles plus claires et de meilleures protections.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La Cour suprême de l’Inde étend progressivement les droits et protections légales des personnes transgenres, montrant une voie différente face à l’opposition mondiale croissante.
articles.personality_title_es: La Corte Suprema de India avanza en derechos transgénero en medio de retrocesos globales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En muchas partes del mundo, los derechos y protecciones para personas transgénero están siendo limitados. Algunos países han cambiado leyes para reducir el reconocimiento y apoyo a personas trans, como eliminar la palabra “transgénero” del lenguaje oficial o restringir el acceso de mujeres trans a ciertos espacios.

**Qué pasó** – La Corte Suprema de India está tomando un camino diferente. Desde hace diez años, reconoce a las personas transgénero como un género legal distinto y les otorga derechos iguales. Recientemente, ordenó formar un comité especial para crear políticas que protejan mejor estos derechos. También ha dictaminado que las mujeres trans son legalmente mujeres y deben tener las mismas protecciones contra abusos.

**Impacto** – Este avance es importante porque muestra un compromiso fuerte con la igualdad en un momento en que muchos países retroceden. India reconoce a las personas trans tanto como un grupo único como mujeres, protegiendo sus derechos sin afectar a otros. Por ejemplo, una mujer trans ganó un caso contra una aerolínea que no respetaba su género legal.

**Próximo paso** – Aunque estas decisiones son prometedoras, queda trabajo por hacer. Algunos casos legales aún esperan resolución y no todas las relaciones trans están plenamente reconocidas. Activistas y tribunales seguirán trabajando para lograr reglas más claras y mejores protecciones.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La Corte Suprema de India avanza en la expansión de derechos y protecciones legales para personas transgénero, marcando un ejemplo en un momento global de oposición creciente.

articles.title: Flags raised in Doha as leaders gather for UN social development summit
articles.summary: Against a quiet morning sky, the flags of the United Nations and the State of Qatar rose together in Doha on Sunday, ahead of the Second World Summit for Social Development.
articles.content:
The ceremony marked the United Nations’ official assumption of the Qatar National Convention Centre (QNCC) as the venue where world leaders will work to reinvigorate the global social pact.

The brief but symbolic event, held at the sprawling conference facility, was attended by senior officials from Qatar and the United Nations, accompanied by a formation of UN security officers and members of Qatar’s Lekhwiya police forces standing on either side of the two flagpoles.

UN Photo/Eskinder Debebe UN protocol and security officers at the flag raising ceremony.

Speaking at the ceremony, Li Junhua, the UN Under-Secretary-General for Economic and Social Affairs, said the moment reflected a shared commitment to cooperation and collective progress.

“This moment formally marks the handover of this landmark facility to the United Nations,” he said. “The QNCC is now transformed into a space where the global community will gather to advance solutions and renew hope.”

Ahmad Hassen Al-Hamadi, Secretary General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Qatar welcomed the international community, emphasising the country’s support as host and partner in facilitating dialogue and cooperation at the highest level.

“We are confident that this Summit will provide a pivotal opportunity to reaffirm the political will and to capitalise on the abundant opportunities to accelerate and stimulate transformative actions to achieve social development and social justice for all, and accelerate progress for the 2030 Agenda [for Sustainable Development].”

A pivotal gathering amid global challenges

Over the next several days, about 14,000 attendees – including Heads of State and Government, ministers, civil society leaders, youth delegates, workers and private sector representatives – will take part in plenaries, high-level roundtables and parallel forums focused on social protection, inequality, decent work and the inclusion of marginalised groups.

In a preview of the Summit last week, UN Spokesperson Stéphane Dujarric confirmed that Secretary-General António Guterres will address the opening ceremony on Tuesday.

Mr. Guterres is expected to highlight progress since the first Social Summit in Copenhagen in 1995, while underscoring major global challenges, including widening inequalities, unemployment, poverty, conflicts and widespread human suffering.

UN Photo/Eskinder Debebe A team of parachutists descend over the QNCC, each carrying a flag representing one of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals.

SDG colours in the sky

Adding a striking visual flourish to Sunday’s ceremony, attention turned to the sky for a special performance organized by the Education Above All Foundation, in cooperation with Qatar’s Internal Security Forces and Joint Special Forces. A team of parachutists descended over the Qatar National Convention Centre, each carrying a flag representing one of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals.

The display symbolized the Foundation’s commitment to advancing education equity and sustainability, while also reflecting the broader aims of the Summit: to accelerate progress on social development and ensure no one is left behind.

The descent drew applause from delegates and onlookers, symbolising the Summit’s themes of unity, shared responsibility and collective action, and visually reinforcing the message that social development is inseparable from the full SDG agenda.

Youth voices take the spotlight

Tweet URL

As leaders gather in Doha, efforts are also under way to bring young people into the conversation. UN DESA has teamed up with Mark Lee, the Korean-Canadian artist from global K-pop group NCT, for a short video message released on social media.

Shot in the style of an incoming video call, the clip shows Mark inviting viewers to “pick up” and reflect on what social progress means to them – from fairness and dignity to real opportunities to thrive.

With millions of followers and a strong global fan base, his message is helping spark conversation among younger audiences who are shaping change in online spaces every day.

“Young and old, we have a huge role to play,” he says in the video. “Our voices, our ideas, our creativity can bring people together. Together, we can show that when we move as one, we can make change happen.”

UN News on the ground

UN News is on the ground in Doha, providing continuing coverage throughout the week, including live updates, interviews and analysis from the Summit. Follow our coverage here.

It highlights global cooperation among leaders, inclusion of youth voices, and efforts to address inequality and social protection, which have broad positive societal impact and substance.
articles.personality_title: World leaders gather in Doha to advance social development goals
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The United Nations is holding its Second World Summit for Social Development at the Qatar National Convention Centre (QNCC) in Doha. This event brings together leaders from around the world to focus on improving social justice, reducing inequality, and supporting the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals.

**What happened** – On Sunday, the UN officially took over the QNCC as the summit venue with a flag-raising ceremony attended by UN and Qatari officials. About 14,000 people, including heads of state, ministers, youth, and civil society representatives, will participate in discussions and forums over the coming days. A special parachute display featured flags representing the 17 Sustainable Development Goals, symbolizing unity and commitment to these targets. Additionally, Korean-Canadian artist Mark Lee helped engage young people by sharing a video message about social progress.

**Impact** – This summit is important because it brings many countries and groups together to work on social challenges like poverty, inequality, and decent work. The event highlights that social development needs cooperation from governments, communities, and youth worldwide. The parachute display and youth involvement show a shared effort to include everyone and keep the goals visible and urgent.

**What's next step** – The summit will continue with high-level talks, roundtables, and workshops where leaders will discuss plans and actions to speed up social progress. UN Secretary-General António Guterres will open the event with a speech reflecting on past progress and current challenges. The outcomes of this summit could influence global policies and partnerships aimed at reaching the 2030 goals.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN Social Development Summit in Doha unites world leaders and communities to renew efforts toward social justice and the Sustainable Development Goals by 2030.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des dirigeants mondiaux réunis à Doha pour faire avancer les objectifs de développement social
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les Nations Unies organisent leur deuxième Sommet mondial sur le développement social au Centre national des congrès du Qatar (QNCC) à Doha. Cet événement rassemble des dirigeants du monde entier pour améliorer la justice sociale, réduire les inégalités et soutenir les Objectifs de développement durable à l’horizon 2030.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Dimanche, l’ONU a officiellement pris possession du QNCC comme lieu du sommet lors d’une cérémonie de levée des drapeaux en présence de responsables qataris et onusiens. Environ 14 000 participants, dont chefs d’État, ministres, jeunes et représentants de la société civile, prendront part à des discussions et forums durant les prochains jours. Un spectacle de parachutistes a arboré les drapeaux des 17 Objectifs de développement durable, symbolisant l’unité et l’engagement envers ces objectifs. De plus, l’artiste coréano-canadien Mark Lee a mobilisé les jeunes avec un message vidéo sur le progrès social.

**Impact** – Ce sommet est important car il réunit de nombreux pays et acteurs pour faire face à des défis sociaux comme la pauvreté, les inégalités et le travail décent. L’événement souligne que le développement social nécessite la coopération des gouvernements, des communautés et des jeunes du monde entier. Le spectacle aérien et la participation des jeunes montrent un effort collectif pour inclure tous les acteurs et maintenir ces objectifs au cœur des priorités.

**Prochaine étape** – Le sommet se poursuivra avec des discussions de haut niveau, des tables rondes et des ateliers où les dirigeants échangeront sur les plans et actions pour accélérer le progrès social. Le Secrétaire général de l’ONU, António Guterres, ouvrira l’événement avec un discours sur les avancées passées et les défis actuels. Les résultats du sommet pourraient influencer les politiques et partenariats mondiaux visant à atteindre les objectifs 2030.

**Une phrase clé** – Le Sommet sur le développement social à Doha rassemble dirigeants et communautés pour renouveler les efforts en faveur de la justice sociale et des Objectifs de développement durable d’ici 2030.
articles.personality_title_es: Líderes mundiales se reúnen en Doha para avanzar en los objetivos de desarrollo social
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Las Naciones Unidas están celebrando su Segunda Cumbre Mundial para el Desarrollo Social en el Centro Nacional de Convenciones de Qatar (QNCC) en Doha. Este evento reúne a líderes de todo el mundo para mejorar la justicia social, reducir la desigualdad y apoyar los Objetivos de Desarrollo Sostenible para 2030.

**Qué pasó** – El domingo, la ONU tomó oficialmente el QNCC como sede de la cumbre con una ceremonia de izamiento de banderas a la que asistieron funcionarios de la ONU y de Qatar. Cerca de 14,000 personas, incluyendo jefes de estado, ministros, jóvenes y representantes de la sociedad civil, participarán en debates y foros durante los próximos días. Un espectáculo de paracaidistas mostró las banderas de los 17 Objetivos de Desarrollo Sostenible, simbolizando unidad y compromiso con estas metas. Además, el artista coreano-canadiense Mark Lee ayudó a involucrar a los jóvenes con un mensaje en video sobre el progreso social.

**Impacto** – Esta cumbre es importante porque reúne a muchos países y grupos para trabajar en desafíos sociales como la pobreza, la desigualdad y el trabajo decente. El evento muestra que el desarrollo social requiere cooperación entre gobiernos, comunidades y jóvenes en todo el mundo. La exhibición aérea y la participación juvenil reflejan un esfuerzo conjunto para incluir a todos y mantener visibles y urgentes los objetivos.

**Próximo paso** – La cumbre continuará con charlas de alto nivel, mesas redondas y talleres donde los líderes discutirán planes y acciones para acelerar el progreso social. El Secretario General de la ONU, António Guterres, inaugurará el evento con un discurso sobre los avances pasados y los desafíos actuales. Los resultados de esta cumbre podrían influir en políticas y asociaciones globales para alcanzar los objetivos 2030.

**Una frase clave** – La Cumbre de Desarrollo Social de la ONU en Doha une a líderes y comunidades para renovar los esfuerzos hacia la justicia social y los Objetivos de Desarrollo Sostenible para 2030.
